>

This study proposes to conduct a thorough review of the Knowledge Management System in the Finance and Administration Section of a state hospital in Malta. It intends to critically analyse and identify gaps within the existing KMS framework and propose enhancements through the application of theoretical models while addressing the unique cultural and operational dynamics of the organization. Knowledge is regarded as an intellectual asset that is not depleted when used, not lost when shared, yet a significant amount of it is often lost by organisations (Dalkir, 2023). Knowledge management (KM) is a systematic approach to acquire, structure, manage and spread knowledge within an organization to enable such to identify and reuse the best and most efficient work practices whilst reduce costly rework from project to project (Nonaka, Toyama, & Konno, 2000; Pasternack & Viscio, 1998; Pfeffer & Sutton, 1999; Ruggles & Holtshouse, 1999). This section outlines the background (section 1.1) and context (section 1.3) of the research, and its purposes (section 1.4). Section 1.5 describes the significance and scope of this research and provides definitions of terms used. Finally, section 1.7 includes an outline of the remaining sections of the assignment.

        "The authors identify a gap in soil health research: diagnostics and management strategies are rarely tailored to the inherent variability of soils. Leveraging the SSURGO database across California’s Central and Coastal Valleys (5.6 M ha), they performed K‑means clustering on ten surface‑soil properties (0–30 cm) plus depth to root‑restrictive horizons. Metrics and validation tests justified a seven‑region conceptual model that distinguishes soils without performance limitations from those limited by (a) root restrictive horizons, (b) salinity/alkalinity, and (c) shrink–swell behavior; further subdividing by texture and/or organic matter into seven coherent regions. This framework offers a testable, place‑based approach for soil health diagnosis and management.",
        "Soil health is the capacity of soil to function as a living ecosystem, supporting plant, animal, and human needs. Research has focused on validating practices (cover crops, reduced tillage, compost) but often overlooks inherent soil variability.

Challenge: Separating effects of management from inherent soil‑forming factors. Prior studies found physiographic region often dominates over management in explaining soil health metrics.

Gap: No region‑wide soil classification tailored to soil health diagnostics in Western U.S.

Objective: Use unsupervised classification of SSURGO‑derived surface properties and root‑restrictive horizons to define soil “health regions” in California’s Central and Coastal Valleys, hypothesizing systematic variability (a) exists at regional scale and (b) differs meaningfully from USDA‑NRCS Soil Taxonomy."
      ]
    },
    {
      "cluster_id": 2,
      "queries": [
        "Research Strategy (≈ 3 000 words)

1. Motivation

Biomedical discovery today remains throttled by the long turnaround time between a clinician’s research question and delivery of an analysable EHR extract.  Even at data‑rich institutions like the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB), investigators wait weeks for database developers to interpret requests, craft SQL, check PHI compliance, and generate CSV files that must then be merged with external resources such as MIMIC‑III.  The friction slows hypothesis iteration and delays translation of discoveries to the bedside.

Large‑language‑model (LLM) breakthroughs—especially open‑weight models that can run safely behind a firewall—offer a path to disrupt this cycle.  Yet merely dropping an LLM into a clinical stack is insufficient: EHR schemas such as OMOP are highly normalised, governed by strict privacy rules, and constantly evolving.  Without specialised agentic orchestration, an LLM will produce fragile queries, omit provenance, and risk PHI leakage.  AgenticAI addresses these challenges head‑on by combining (i) on‑premise, high‑capacity LLM serving; (ii) an ensemble of purpose‑built LangChain agents; and (iii) a first‑class privacy layer grounded in differential privacy, federated execution, and Named‑Entity‑Recognition (NER) redaction.

2. Gaps in the Current Landscape

#

Gap

Implications

G1

Lack of real‑time PHI‑safe conversational interfaces for OMOP/EHR data.

Investigators rely on manual SQL triage, delaying analysis and stifling exploratory work.

G2

Cloud‑only LLM services create data‑sovereignty, latency, and cost barriers.

Health‑system privacy officers reject cloud APIs for PHI; GPU costs escalate unpredictably.

G3

Generic NLP query tools ignore OMOP vocabularies and clinical ontologies.

Generates incorrect joins, misinterprets clinical codes, undermines trust.

G4

Fragmented privacy safeguards (tokenisation, access control) lack formal guarantees.

Cannot quantify re‑identification risk; auditors block data release.

G5

Little benchmarking of agent architectures (RAG vs SQL‑Agents) in large, normalised clinical warehouses.

Institutions risk committing to sub‑optimal pipelines that cannot scale.

3. How This Proposal Closes the Gaps

Gap Addressed

Solution Element

G1

Natural‑language ChatUtility powered by agentic orchestration; immediate cohort counts, plots, and exportable code snippets.

G2

On‑premise Ollama cluster running LLAMA3‑405B & Deepseek R1; eliminates data egress risk, slashes latency, yields predictable GPU utilisation.

G3

Fine‑tuning on OMOP CDM + LOINC + SNOMED CT; schema‑aware prompt templates; continuous schema‑diff monitoring.

G4

Built‑in differential privacy (ε ≤ 3) for numeric outputs; federated query execution so raw tables remain siloed; NER redaction for free‑text columns; immutable audit logs.

G5

Rigorous head‑to‑head evaluation of Retrieval‑Augmented Generation (RAG) versus LangChain SQL‑Agent pipelines on precision, latency, extensibility, and maintenance burden.

4. Significance

Timely, privacy‑compliant access to comprehensive EHR data is a linchpin for precision medicine, real‑world evidence studies, and rapid clinical decision support.  Yet the gaps identified above (G1–G5) collectively stall discovery and inflate costs: manual query cycles delay hypotheses; cloud LLM prohibitions deny clinicians modern AI tools; schema ignorance breeds mistrust; and incomplete privacy controls hinder data‑sharing collaborations.  AgenticAI directly responds to these pain points with an integrated, on‑premise, privacy‑preserving solution.

Accelerates Translational Science: By collapsing data‑access turnaround from weeks to minutes, AgenticAI empowers investigators to iterate rapidly, increasing the velocity of grant‑funded research and improving time‑to‑publication.

Enhances Patient Safety & Equity: Secure, role‑governed self‑service analytics help reveal care disparities and treatment‑response patterns sooner, enabling evidence‑based interventions for under‑served populations.

Amplifies NIH Investments: The platform leverages and extends community standards (OMOP CDM, OpenDP, LangChain), maximising reuse of NIH‑funded resources such as MIMIC‑III and facilitating multi‑centre synergy across CTSA hubs.

Sets a Compliance Benchmark: Embedding DataLENS policy decisions, differential privacy, and federated execution establishes a replicable blueprint for HIPAA‑aligned AI research, lowering barriers for institutions facing similar regulatory hurdles.

By uniting these advances, AgenticAI transforms gap‑ridden EHR analytics into a scalable, trustworthy, and institutionally compliant ecosystem—exactly the paradigm envisioned by RFA‑OD‑24‑010 to harness emerging AI technologies for biomedical research.",

queries: a literature review of the Devonian rocks of southeast Saskatchewan

Here are two title options based on the gaps: Option 1: "Biogeochemical Controls on Early Diagenetic Cementation and Porosity Evolution in the Upper Devonian Duperow Formation, Saskatchewan" Option 2: "Microbial Mediation and Fluid Geochemistry in the Diagenetic History of Upper Devonian Carbonates: A Case Study from the Duperow Formation"

�� Research Problem / Rationale Although the sedimentological and microfacies characteristics of the Duperow Formation have been well documented, its biogeochemical evolution remains poorly understood. In particular, there has been limited investigation into the origins of early cementing fluids and the role of microbial processes in driving dolomitization, sulfate mineral precipitation (e.g., celestite, anhydrite), and porosity modification. These unknowns represent a significant gap in understanding how geochemical and microbial processes influence reservoir quality, especially in shallow marine carbonate-evaporite systems with hydrocarbon potential. �� Research Objectives Characterize the geochemical signature (δ¹³C, δ¹⁸O, δ³⁴S, ⁸⁷Sr/⁸⁶Sr, trace elements) of diagenetic cements (dolomite, anhydrite, celestite, calcite) in the Duperow Formation. Identify evidence of microbial mediation (e.g., framboidal pyrite, biomarkers, microbial textures) in early diagenesis. Determine the origin and evolution of pore fluids responsible for cementation and mineral replacement. Assess the impact of biogeochemical processes on porosity development and reservoir quality. �� Methodology (Overview) Petrography: Thin-section analysis to classify cement types, textures, and paragenetic sequences. SEM-EDS & Cathodoluminescence: Identify crystal fabrics, celestite/cement associations, and possible microbial structures. Stable Isotope Analysis: δ¹³C and δ¹⁸O for carbonate cements δ³⁴S and δ¹⁸O for sulfate minerals ⁸⁷Sr/⁸⁶Sr for fluid source tracing Organic Geochemistry (if accessible): Biomarker analysis (e.g., hopanes, steranes) for microbial activity. Fluid Inclusion Analysis: Estimate temperature and composition of diagenetic fluids. �� Study Area & Sample Base Focus on cores from the Seward Member of the Duperow Formation (especially Units with early cementation and anhydrite/celestite presence as per Lake 2004 and Cen & Salad Hersi 2006). �� Expected Outcomes A clearer model of early fluid-rock interactions and their diagenetic signatures Identification of microbial versus abiotic processes in cementation and mineralization Insights into reservoir potential in analogous carbonate-evaporite systems A biogeochemical framework that supports future hydrocarbon exploration or CO₂ sequestration models

The biogeochemical evolution of the Duperow Formation, particularly in southern Saskatchewan, remains less well understood due to a lack of significant hydrocarbon production in the region compared to coeval strata like the Leduc reefs of Alberta and the Duperow Formation in North Dakota. This disparity is attributed to the less understood stratigraphic, sedimentological, and diagenetic aspects of the formation in southern Saskatchewan.

queries: What are the Current Applications and Future Perspectives for Circulating Tumor DNA in Genitourinary Malignancies?

How do the fundamental biological principles of ctDNA (including its origin, release mechanisms, and molecular characteristics) alongside the evolving landscape of pre-analytical and analytical technologies (spanning PCR-based methods, diverse NGS applications, and emerging platforms) collectively enable the reliable detection, quantification, and comprehensive genomic/epigenomic profiling of ctDNA in patients with genitourinary malignancies, and what are the inherent technical challenges and bioinformatics considerations that must be addressed to ensure robust and reproducible results?

What is the current evidence-based clinical utility of ctDNA analysis across the spectrum of major genitourinary malignancies (prostate, urothelial, renal cell, and testicular germ cell tumors) in diverse clinical contexts—including early detection/diagnosis, risk stratification, prognostication, real-time monitoring of therapeutic response, detection of minimal residual disease, and identification of resistance mechanisms—and how does its performance compare to or complement existing standard-of-care biomarkers and imaging modalities?

Beyond single-gene mutation detection, how are advanced applications of ctDNA—such as the assessment of tumor mutational burden (TMB), microsatellite instability (MSI), ctDNA methylation patterns, and the characterization of tumor heterogeneity and clonal evolution—being leveraged in genitourinary oncology, and what is the potential of integrating ctDNA data with other liquid biopsy analytes (e.g., CTCs, exosomes) or imaging to provide a more holistic and dynamic understanding of tumor biology and treatment response?

What are the critical scientific, technical, logistical, and economic challenges (including lack of standardization, need for rigorous prospective validation, interpretation of complex genomic data like VUS or CHIP, and cost-effectiveness) that currently hinder the widespread, equitable clinical implementation of ctDNA testing in genitourinary oncology, and what are the paramount ethical, legal, and social implications (ELSI) that must be proactively addressed to ensure responsible innovation and patient protection?

Looking ahead, how are anticipated technological breakthroughs, the integration of artificial intelligence/machine learning, the development of malignancy-specific ctDNA assays, and innovative clinical trial designs poised to overcome current limitations and unlock the full transformative potential of ctDNA in genitourinary cancer care, potentially revolutionizing early detection, personalized treatment selection, dynamic response monitoring, and ultimately improving patient outcomes across the disease continuum?

queries: Novelty Assessment in PeerReviews
variation in peer review at AI conferences. Variation in novelty assessment by reviewers.

In the last few years, review quality have deteriorated a lot. One reason for this is the scale of papers submitted in a review cycle. Reviewer workload has grown a lot over the past few years. Secondly, a lot of junior reviewers fail to produce good quality reviews. Novelty Assessment which is a subtask of peer reviewing has suffered due to it being a very time and knowledge intensive task requiring the reviewer to consult literature relevant to the paper and figure out if the submission brings any novelty to the table. Often due to its nature specifically w.r.t NLP conferences reviewers hardly explicitly state any novelty assessments (that is if they do any in the first place). In this paper we work on building an AI assisted workflow for the task of novelty assessment. We show how simple RAG based approaches used previously fail at acomplishing the task and how a more structured prompt improves in providing a better result.

        "Implementing restorative justice in Morocco presents both significant opportunities and challenges. Restorative justice, which focuses on repairing harm caused by criminal behavior through cooperative processes that include all stakeholders, offers a transformative approach to the traditional punitive justice system. Here’s an analysis of the opportunities and challenges in the Moroccan context:",
        "In Morocco, there are three classes of Child Detention Center: the National Juvenile Centers reserved for serious young offenders, the Centers for the Safeguarding of Childhood which handle those convicted of lesser offences and also houses a social services section which receives and protects children at risk, and the Centers for the Preparation of Reintegration which offer post-incarceration programs for social reintegration. Restorative justice could be introduced at any of these institutions with a view to facilitating indirect or direct dialogue between offenders and victims (or, as in the case of Sycamore Tree, with surrogate victims). Equally, restorative justice could be used to transform the response to resident–resident, staff–resident or staff–staff conflicts in any of these institutions in much the same way that Search for Common Ground has used techniques of mediation in Moroccan prisons to these ends. Irrespective of which approach is taken, such a project would have the potential to benefit the employees and residents of any such institution, as well as their families, victims and Moroccan society as a whole.",
        "In Morocco, it would be possible to build on and learn from the ways in which other Islamic and non-Islamic societies have used restorative justice with crime. It would also be pertinent to examine the Moroccan experience of ADR and the Equity and Reconciliation Commission. Moreover, it is important to recognize the significance of cultural differences in the way that justice is both perceived and done, but not to exaggerate such differences, instead placing emphasis on commonalities and utilizing flexible and responsive techniques, of which restorative justice is just one example. The assessment of creative writing includes multiple structured systematic frameworks. The Torrance Test for Creative Thinking (TTCT) (Torrance, 1966) has served as a foundational assessment model for evaluating creativity and has been widely applied in the assessment of creative writing (Chakrabarty et al., 2024). Another well-known assessment model is SOLO (Structure of the Observed Learning Outcome) taxonomy (Biggs & Collis, 1982), which outlines creative writing competencies into five levels (Chakrabarty et al., 2024). To establish a more comprehensive framework, Tredinnick’s guidelines emerged as an additional approach for defining and structuring creative writing (Alwasilah, 2024). More recently, some scholars have developed and rigorously validated a structured analytical rubric as another evaluation framework categorizing nine elements to evaluate creative writing (Vaezi & Rezaei, 2019).

It will also develop new algorithms and satellite data products using machine learning based multi-sensor fusion algorithms to combine the products from different sensors on different satellites.

Overview: The extent of habitable conditions on other planets in the solar system – in particular, the existence of water environments – is a fundamental question for planetary exploration, guiding NASA’s current and planned Mars Sample Return missions and future human exploration. Mars is now known to have hosted localized, short duration liquid water environments at its surface and shallow subsurface, with potentially extensive liquid water environments deep in its crust, however the duration, depths and geographic distribution of these environments are still poorly known, as are their potential habitability. Identifying locations where water and conditions that could potentially support life have occurred near the surface of Mars, or have persisted for significant periods of time, are of high importance: not just for their scientific significance in understanding the potential implications for biology, but also for identifying shallow subsurface water resources that could be accessed by crewed missions. Secondly, there is a diversity of satellite sensors gathering data across the electromagnetic spectrum, at differing spatial, spectral, and temporal resolutions. There is a compelling need to combine the data from different sensors to generate new products that have optimised spectral and spatial resolution and mitigate the limitations inherent to any one single sensor.

Aims: The primary aim of the research project is to map the extent of the habitable regions of Mars throughout time using water/ice related impact morphologies, and identify regions where potential habitable environments may have persisted near to the surface, or for long periods of time. The secondary aim is to develop new algorithms and satellite data products using machine learning based multi-sensor fusion algorithms to combine the products from different sensors on different satellites thereby filling data acquisition gaps.

Objectives: The objectives of this work are to quantify the extent of potentially habitable environments (PHEs) within the crust of Mars, where a habitable environment can be considered most broadly as one which supports: liquid water of varying plausible chemistries (brines), within a range of temperatures appropriate for terrestrial microorganisms. The existence of habitable conditions will be probed using a subset of impact craters that likely to have formed from the presence of water/ice in the subsurface. A range of satellite datasets will be used by the candidate to constrain the depth to, water concentration, salinity of, and age of the PHE, including: impact crater morphometry, mineralogy, rock and grain-sizes and their distribution. The remote sensing datasets used will include: high resolution camera imagery, elevation, thermal inertia, and multi-and hyperspectral data across the visible, shortwave infrared and thermal wavelengths from a range of sensors and satellites. The candidate will take existing machine learning image fusion algorithms, and further develop them to the unique application of infilling the particular temporal, spectral and spatial gaps of Mars satellite sensors to generate novel satellite data products at enhanced spectral and spatial resolutions than what is currently available. The output of the work will be maps of high priority PHE that occur near-surface, or zones where PHEs cluster and or conditions of habitability are likely to have persisted for a significant period of time.

Significance: The outcomes of this work are significant for enhancing the knowledge capacity of past, present, current and future space-based datasets, through the development of innovative algorithmic tools specifically designed to address the wide gaps in satellite data coverage, thereby improving the potential knowledge and insights from future Australian’s sensors and contributing key new knowledge for both the Australian and the global space sector.         "Introduction: partial Shading Effects on PV Array
Partial shading (PS) is one of the most significant challenges in photovoltaic (PV) array operation, causing substantial power losses and reducing system efficiency. When shadows cover portions of a PV array, they create non-uniform irradiance conditions across the modules, resulting in "the highest harm effect on the produced PV array power and its lifetime."

(Yousri et al., 2020)

The impact of partial shading extends beyond simple power reduction, as it creates multiple peaks in the output characteristics, making it difficult for maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithms to locate the global maximum power point.

(Zhu et al., 2020)

The fundamental challenge with partial shading arises from the series-parallel connections in conventional PV arrays. In series-connected modules, the module receiving the lowest irradiance limits the current of the entire string, causing significant power losses even when only a small portion of the array is shaded. This mismatch between modules leads to the formation of bypass diodes, which create multiple power peaks in the P-V characteristic curve and reduce the overall energy harvesting capability of the system. (Ameen et al., 2023)
To mitigate these adverse effects, array reconfiguration has emerged as a promising solution. By dynamically adjusting the electrical connections between PV modules, reconfiguration techniques aim to distribute shadows more effectively across the array and minimize their impact on power production. (Yousri et al., 2020)

This approach is particularly effective because it directly addresses the fundamental issue of current mismatch in partially shaded arrays.
Traditional reconfiguration strategies have primarily focused on the principle of irradiance equalization, which aims to distribute modules with similar irradiance levels within the same rows to minimize current mismatch. While this approach works effectively in many shading scenarios, research has shown that it has limitations, particularly "when the irradiance of individual modules differs greatly," where "no matter how the PV modules are rearranged, a uniform row current cannot be obtained." 
(Zhu et al., 2020)

In such cases, irradiance equalization strategies may not yield optimal results and could potentially decrease the maximum output power.
More advanced approaches have been developed to overcome these limitations, including hierarchical-based switching block schemes that enable more flexible reconfiguration of PV arrays. These systems employ multiple levels of switching blocks to adapt effectively to complex shading patterns, offering "a balance between low complexity, scalability, and superior energy harvesting efficiency."

(Ameen et al., 2023)

When compared to conventional configurations such as bridge-linked (BL), total-cross-tied (TCT), and series-parallel (SP), these dynamic reconfiguration techniques have demonstrated significant improvements in power generation—up to 42.52% increase in some cases—making them valuable solutions for practical PV applications operating under variable shading conditions.

(Ameen et al., 2023)",
        "Photovoltaic (PV) array reconfiguration techniques under partial shading conditions have witnessed significant advancements in recent years. The traditional restructuring approach primarily focused on the irradiance equalization principle, which aims to group PV modules with similar levels of radiation within the same rows or columns to reduce current mismatch. However, research has demonstrated limitations of this approach, particularly when irradiance varies widely among units. In such cases, no matter how the solar modules are rearranged, achieving a uniform current across a row is impossible (Chu et al., 2020).
Under these circumstances, the irradiance equalization strategy may not only fail to optimize power output but can even reduce the maximum power generated by the reconfigured array.
To address these limitations, researchers have proposed more advanced approaches that directly assess and maximize the power capacity generated by the solar array. Chu et al. (2020) formulated the reconfiguration problem as a 0-1 Multi-Knapsack Problem and developed a mathematical model that goes beyond simple current balancing to find genuinely optimal configurations. This method marks a significant step forward compared to previous techniques, as it simultaneously considers both current and voltage characteristics during optimization.
Dynamic reconfiguration algorithms have also emerged as a promising trend. These algorithms modify the electrical connections of PV modules in real time in response to changing shading conditions. Vicenti et al. (2015) introduced a method for dynamic reshaping of arrays connected in a serial-branched form that preserves the physical dimensions of the matrix while reorganizing electrical connections to reduce shading impacts. Their approach relies on Rough Set Theory, enabling fast and efficient control system implementations capable of real-time optimal configuration determination (Vicenti et al., 2015).
Similarly, Cherukuri et al. (2021) proposed a dynamic reconfiguration algorithm based solely on current measurements to estimate shadow dispersion rates and perform reconfiguration. This significantly reduces the number of sensors needed compared to existing PV matrix reconfiguration techniques (Cherukuri et al., 2021).
Switch-based methods have gained growing attention due to their flexibility in implementing various reconfiguration strategies. Vadivel et al. (2021) described an optimization scheme for a 4×4 sequential-branch connected matrix using a switching matrix to ensure equal current flow through each column. Their method divides the array into multiple sections and swaps connections to equalize column currents, producing a P-V curve with a single smooth peak. For situations where full current equalization is unattainable, they proposed supplementing reconfiguration with current injection—injecting current into the column with the lowest current flow equal to the difference between the highest and lowest column currents (Vadivel et al., 2021).
More recently, Fang et al. (2022) developed a dynamic reconfiguration method applicable to both Total-Cross-Tied (TCT) and Series-Parallel (SP) interconnected PV arrays of any size. Their approach uses a switching matrix to create flexible connections between PV strings and inverters, dynamically adjusting electrical connections based on mismatch conditions. Simulation results showed that this method outperforms fixed-topology schemes under various mismatch scenarios, achieving average maximum power point improvements of 8.56% for TCT arrays and 6.43% for SP arrays (Fang et al., 2022).
Advanced architectural approaches have also been explored to enhance reconfiguration capabilities. Niazi et al. (2021) proposed a reconfiguration technique utilizing a switched-capacitor-based voltage equalizer with differential power processing for optimization at cell, subpanel, and panel levels. Their active charge redistribution architecture increases energy yield during mismatch conditions and provides voltage boosting when no mismatch exists by connecting PV cells or panels in series. The system monitors voltage and irradiance across each panel and performs reconfiguration accordingly, switching from series connections to differential power processing upon detecting mismatch (Niazi et al., 2021).
Perhaps the most promising recent advancement is the hierarchical-based switching block scheme introduced by Ameen et al. (2023). This design employs multiple levels of switching blocks to enable efficient and flexible PV array reconfiguration under complex shading patterns. The architecture strikes "a balance between low complexity, scalability, and superior energy harvesting efficiency," making it suitable for practical applications.

Decentralized AI at the Edge: Federated Learning, Quantum Optimization, and IoT Scalability

Abstract
Decentralized artificial intelligence (AI) at the edge represents a transformative shift in computing paradigms, driven by the integration of federated learning, quantum optimization, and Internet of Things (IoT) scalability. This paper explores the confluence of these technologies, emphasizing their role in enhancing edge AI's efficiency, privacy preservation, and scalability. A comprehensive literature review reveals the advancements and challenges in federated learning and quantum optimization, particularly in IoT contexts. The methodology section outlines a framework for deploying federated learning models optimized through quantum techniques to address IoT scalability challenges. Results indicate significant improvements in model accuracy and resource efficiency. The discussion highlights the implications for edge computing developers, AI researchers, and IoT system architects. The conclusion addresses current limitations and proposes directions for future research in decentralized AI systems.

Keywords: Edge AI, Federated Learning, Quantum Optimization, IoT Scalability, Privacy Preservation.

Write a comprehensive article exploring the criteria for distinguishing treaties from non-legally binding international agreements. Begin with an introduction explaining the importance of international agreements in global governance and the purpose of the article. Provide examples and case studies of treaties (e.g., Paris Agreement, NATO Charter), non-binding agreements (e.g., Iran Deal, G7 communiqués), and ambiguous cases (e.g., U.S.-China Phase One Trade Deal).

Discuss challenges in classification, such as ambiguous language, evolving state practice, and the role of international courts. Analyze the implications of misclassification, including legal consequences and impacts on state sovereignty. Conclude by examining future trends, such as the rise of soft law, and provide recommendations for clear drafting and adherence to VCLT principles. Conclude with recommendations for the ILC and practitioners, emphasizing the need for clear drafting, the hybrid approach, and the rejection of default presumptions. Address future trends, such as the rise of soft law in areas like cybersecurity and climate governance. Summarize the importance of resolving these issues to uphold legal certainty and strengthen global governance.

The ability to map and understand brain activity has revolutionized neuroscience through various imaging techniques (Pollonini et al., 2016). Among these methods, Electroencephalography (EEG) and functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) have emerged as particularly accessible and practical approaches for measuring brain function (Arif et al., 2024). EEG operates by directly measuring electrical signals through scalp electrodes, providing immediate feedback on neural activity (Arif et al., 2024) (Praveena et al., 2020). In contrast, fNIRS works by measuring changes in blood oxygen levels in the brain, specifically tracking variations in oxyhemoglobin and deoxyhemoglobin concentrations within the 650-1000 nm spectral range (Pollonini et al., 2016). A notable advantage of fNIRS is its practicality - it is non-harmful, portable, and relatively cost-effective compared to other brain imaging methods like fMRI (Pollonini et al., 2016) (Pinti et al., 2018). These characteristics make fNIRS particularly suitable for diverse research settings and participant populations, from newborns to elderly individuals, both within and outside laboratory environments (Pinti et al., 2018). Each technique offers distinct advantages in terms of resolution: EEG provides excellent temporal resolution but limited spatial precision, while fNIRS delivers better spatial resolution but slower temporal response due to the inherent delay in blood oxygen level changes (Arif et al., 2024). 15 خط دیگر اضافه کن

Le Maroc . Cette vulnérabilité accrue s’explique par la forte dépendance du secteur agricole à la pluviométrie, notamment pour les céréales et les cultures vivrières. Même sous un scénario durable (SSP1), la baisse reste significative (–0,9 %/an). Le pays a pourtant déployé des stratégies d’adaptation à travers le Plan Maroc Vert puis la Stratégie Génération Green, mais ces efforts devront être intensifiés pour limiter les pertes futures. L’agriculture marocaine nécessite des transformations structurelles : extension de l’irrigation goutte-à-goutte, sélection variétale, assurance climatique, et adaptation des systèmes de production aux conditions arides renforcées.

La Tunisie suit une trajectoire très proche de celle du Maroc, avec des pertes estimées à –0,8 %, –1,7 % et –4,0 % par an selon les scénarios. Cette situation met en lumière la forte exposition du pays aux risques climatiques, aggravée par une surexploitation des ressources hydriques et une faible efficacité de l’irrigation traditionnelle. Les régions du Centre et du Sud, déjà vulnérables, pourraient connaître des baisses de rendement alarmantes. Dans ce contexte, la Tunisie doit accélérer l’intégration de politiques d’adaptation dans sa planification agricole, en combinant innovations techniques, gouvernance de l’eau et soutien ciblé aux exploitants les plus exposés.

La Mauritanie affiche les pertes les plus faibles dans chaque scénario (–0,7 %, –1,5 %, –3,7 %), ce qui pourrait sembler refléter une moindre exposition. En réalité, cela s’explique surtout par le poids encore limité de l’agriculture dans l’économie nationale, fortement concentrée dans la vallée du fleuve Sénégal. Toutefois, une baisse de près de 4 % par an dans un pays où l’insécurité alimentaire touche déjà une large partie de la population représenterait un défi considérable. Le renforcement de l’irrigation, la lutte contre l’ensablement et le soutien aux cultures pastorales et pluviales s’imposent comme des priorités stratégiques.

En Algérie, les projections indiquent une dégradation progressive de la production agricole selon l’intensité du scénario climatique retenu. Sous SSP1–2.6, la baisse reste relativement modérée, estimée à –0,8 % par an, ce qui traduit un certain potentiel de résilience dans un contexte de politiques climatiques actives. En revanche, sous SSP2–4.5, la perte double quasiment (–1,7 %/an), ce qui reflète une vulnérabilité croissante face à une intensification des stress hydriques et thermiques. Le scénario SSP5–8.5 projette une chute annuelle de –3,8 %, ce qui, sur le long terme, représenterait une contraction majeure de la production. Ces résultats soulignent la nécessité pour l’Algérie de renforcer ses politiques d’adaptation, notamment en matière de gestion de l’eau, de diversification des cultures, et de renforcement de la productivité dans les zones irriguées.

la Libye apparaît particulièrement vulnérable, selon les scénarios SSP1, SSP2 et SSP5 respectivement. Ce pays, déjà caractérisé par des contraintes agroclimatiques extrêmes et une forte dépendance aux eaux fossiles pour l’irrigation, pourrait voir sa capacité agricole se réduire drastiquement en l’absence d’investissements massifs dans l’adaptation. L’aggravation des conditions climatiques dans un contexte de fragilité institutionnelle rend la question agricole particulièrement critique.

L’Égypte présente une trajectoire relativement similaire à celle de l’Algérie, bien que légèrement moins marquée sous le scénario SSP1–2.6 (–0,7 %/an). Cette résilience relative pourrait s’expliquer par la forte prédominance de l’irrigation dans le système agricole égyptien. Toutefois, à partir du scénario SSP2–4.5, la baisse atteint –1,6 % par an, traduisant une sensibilité accrue aux températures extrêmes et à la disponibilité hydrique liée au Nil.
